WHAT MAKES THIS BULL CYCLE DIFFERENT FROM OTHER CYCLE   This Bitcoin $BTC  cycle is structurally different from past bull markets.  Historically, price surged first, retail FOMO followed, and on-chain congestion peaked near cycle tops. This time, congestion and fee pressure appeared at the very start of the cycle ‚Äî aligned with the launch of BlackRock‚Äôs IBIT spot ETF.  KEY DIFFERENCE:  - Early demand came from institutions via ETFs, not retail on-chain speculation  - Institutions front-loaded exposure, instead of chasing late-cycle momentum  - On-chain congestion peaked early, reflecting structural positioning, not euphoria  - Price expansion followed with muted retail participation  - The ETF era didn‚Äôt end the cycle ‚Äî it started it.  This isn‚Äôt a late-stage retail bubble. It‚Äôs early institutional positioning marking Bitcoin‚Äôs maturation phase.

According to Ted (@TedPillows), BlackRock‚Äôs Bitcoin ETF ‚ÄúIBIT‚Äù has printed its first-ever death cross.

This technical signal occurs when the short-term moving average falls below the long-term moving average, typically suggesting a phase where short-term corrections or unstable price action should be watched closely.

That said, for ETFs, supply and demand‚Äînamely capital inflows and outflows‚Äîplay an overwhelmingly large role. Relying solely on technical signals to judge the medium- to long-term trend can therefore be misleading.

Alongside price-based signals, it is important to calmly monitor changes in fund flows.

According to Crypto Rover, Bitcoin has printed a bearish MACD cross on the monthly (1M) chart.

In past four-year cycles, this signal has often preceded a transition into a bear market. The main exception was the 2019‚Äì2020 period, when a major liquidity shift occurred‚ÄîQT ended, T-bill purchases began, and QE was ultimately launched.

This highlights that what truly matters is not technical signals in isolation, but the liquidity environment. Whether this cycle follows the same path or becomes another exception will largely depend on upcoming monetary policy decisions.

Europeans Use Crypto for Everyday Purchases: WhiteBIT Report  According to WhiteBIT‚Äôs report, Europeans are increasingly using cryptocurrency for everyday expenses, such as groceries, cafes, and bill payments. This shift highlights the growing adoption of crypto as a functional tool rather than just a speculative asset.  Key Takeaways:  Stablecoins dominate crypto spending, with USDC, USDT, and EURI leading the way, while $BTC  is less commonly used for purchases.  WhiteBIT Nova, a crypto debit card, processed over ‚Ç¨50 million in transactions, with users spending between ‚Ç¨500 to ‚Ç¨1000 per month.  81% of users prefer virtual cards over physical ones, reflecting the increasing trend of mobile-first financial behavior.  Europe‚Äôs embrace of digital financial tools is growing, especially in countries like Spain, Italy, Ireland, Poland, and Netherlands, where crypto payments are becoming routine. Stablecoins are preferred for daily spending, while cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin are primarily used for long-term holdings.  This quiet yet significant trend indicates that crypto cards are no longer a futuristic novelty - they‚Äôre becoming a normal part of the financial landscape in Europe

Fifteen years ago today, Satoshi Nakamoto logged into the Bitcoin forum for the last time and vanished. No manifesto, no grand vision, not even a "good luck."

The moment he disappeared, he completed the institutional loop‚Äîtransitioning from technical decentralization to the decentralization of cognition and authority.

In terms of human evolution, the creator of new production relations stands far above the creator of productive forces. He saw clearly that once "trust" becomes a prerequisite for a system, that system is destined to collapse (sustained only by massive friction costs until it does).

So, he created a new set of production relations, stripping trust from the institution. His system is self-consistent, relying solely on game theory and mathematics. Almost single-handedly, he enabled a quantum leap in human production relations. In my view, his influence rivals that of the Code of Hammurabi‚Äîcodifying power into law/grammar.

The Bitcoin in his wallets is now worth up to $100 billion, yet not a single satoshi has ever moved.

Over the past decade, I have repeatedly pondered the few words he left behind. His insight, restraint, execution, character, and demeanor move me deeply and have benefited me for a lifetime.
